column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=3 .
#Text=Results
#Text=One of the requirements for applying the multilevel analysis technique is that the between-groups variance of the dependent variable is significant .

#Text=To verify this , a variance decomposition model will be used with a single factor coinciding with the grouping variable , in this case the region , in which explanatory variables are not included .
#Text=Due to its basic character , this model is known in the literature as null model or empty model .
#Text=The first column of Table 5 shows the results of the estimation of this model .
#Text=The inter-region variance is estimated at 0.26 with a standard error of 0.19 .
#Text=The likelihood ratio test has a value of 7.56 with an associated p-value of less than 0.01 .
#Text=This result confirms the existence of a non-zero inter-region variance , and therefore , justifies the application of the multilevel analysis technique .

#Text=From these values it is possible to calculate the intra-class correlation ( ICC ) as a representative measure of the variation percentage of the dependent variable which is attributable to differences between the regions .

#Text=In this case , it is observed that most of the variation in the dependent variable has its origin in the differences between farms , while 7.3 % of this said variance , based on the CCI value , can be attributed to differences in regional factors .

#Text=Although it may seem like an influence of reduced magnitude , it is a logical value , since the intra-class correlation tends to be smaller the larger the theoretical dimension of the group , its value oscillating between 0.05 and 0.85 % , for example , when the group identifies with the region .
#Text=Regarding the selection of explanatory variables , we follow a stepwise strategy .
#Text=Thus , in the first model ( Model 1 ) only variables at the farm level are entered , so that it is possible to establish comparisons with previous studies .
#Text=Then , in a second estimate , the model is expanded to incorporate the regional level variables ( Model 2 ) .

#Text=The inclusion of the regional characteristics results in a slight improvement of the Akaike Information Criterion ( AIC ) ( from a value of 457.45 to a value of 457.15 ) , while the goodness of fit measures considered ( pseudo-R2 ) exhibit an appreciable increase .
#Text=In Model 3 , we intend to isolate the effect of the contextual variables related to the action of regional authorities ( CAPACITY and R&D ) .
#Text=As shown in Table 5 , this most parsimonious model gives rise to an improvement of the Akaike Information Criterion ( AIC ) , as compared to Model 2 .
#Text=As for explanatory variables pertaining to the farm dimension , the results point to four statistically significant variables .

#Text=Three of them , PROFES , PERMANENT and SIZE , which have a relevant and positive effect on the probability that the farm will invest in renewable energies , refer to the characteristics of the farm , while the fourth , EDUCATION , corresponds to a characteristic of the person in charge .
#Text=With regard to , firstly , the characteristics of the farm , as expected , the dimension ( SIZE ) is an element that determines the willingness to invest in renewable energy .
#Text=It is well known that business size is an indicator that serves as a proxy for the set of financial and human resources of a company .
#Text=In this sense , it is logical that the larger the farm size , the greater the probability of embarking on new projects other than the main activity .

#Text=This result , together with the positive effect of the PROFES and PERMANENT variables that represent , respectively , their legal status and workforce stability , demonstrate that management professionalization and the solidity of the farm are elements that work in favor of investment in a renewable infrastructure .

#Text=This could be in line with the opinion of authors who believe that this type of investment is favored by the farm ’s orientation towards obtaining an economic profit , which would be achieved through a strategy of production diversification .
#Text=On the other hand , other variables referring to the farm characteristics do not have statistically significant coefficients .

#Text=Thus , PROPERTY , which includes the fact that most of the surface of the farm is owned by the person in charge , has a positive parameter associated , consistent with literature , which points to the fact that the ownership of the farm favors investment in renewables ; although in this case this relationship is not statistically significant .
#Text=The same applies to ECO , which indicates whether the holding is dedicated to organic farming , which in the opinion of several authors favors investment in renewables .
#Text=The positive sign of the coefficient is consistent with this opinion , although the estimated relationship is not statistically significant .
